awd_titl_txt: Estimation of Critical Battery States via Strain and Stress Measurement
awd_abstract_narration:
Energy storage utilizing lithium-ion batteries is ubiquitous from cell phones and satellites to vehicles and the electric grid. All these applications require reliable estimates of the available power and energy. Consumer concerns, such as range anxiety for Electric Vehicles (EVs), hamper market penetration. Such concerns can be alleviated by improving estimates of critical battery states such as capacity and internal resistance that change over time. This research seeks to address those concerns by improving battery health diagnostics.  This advance will benefit all battery-powered devices and could be especially crucial for the second-life use of automotive batteries for energy storage on the electric grid which has the potential to enable more substantial penetration of renewable resources through expanded utilization of existing battery technology. Experimentally validated models of the battery mechanical response and its connection to battery health would fill a critical gap in the availability of public-domain data and models. 

The state of the art battery estimation methods relies on the cell terminal voltage measurements, and the plan is to improve the battery health diagnostics in this project by measuring and interpreting the battery cell expansion which happens when the electrode layers fill and empty with lithium-ions during charging and discharging.  This research aims to create a multi-physics model and estimation techniques to harness the information in the deformation of the electrodes and to analyze the measured electrical and mechanical signals to enhance battery health estimation. The graphite electrode exhibits distinct expansion patterns as it fills with lithium-ions, which can enable diagnosis of electrode-specific degradation. Several fundamental gaps in the modeling of multi-scale inter-dependent thermal, electrochemical and mechanical responses of the battery need to be addressed before the benefits of this approach can be realized in relevant usage cycles involving dynamic charging and discharging. Moreover, the accuracy of joint state and parameter estimation depends on the operating region and the current excitation or usage profile. Systematic techniques to assess the identifiability would benefit from physics-based models that can be used to investigate the influence of various degradation mechanisms, cross-sensitivity with thermal swelling, sensor location, and commercially relevant packaging.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Summary of Results: We proved that battery swelling observed as graphite anodes filled with Lithium can provide rich information on the battery's state of health. We developed models for interpreting the swelling measurements. We developed a physics-based low-order mechanical single particle battery model (mSPM) of the coupled electro-chemical and thermomechanical dynamics [1]–[3]. The model captures the intrinsic shift of the phase transition of the battery material as it ages from loss of active or cyclable Lithium material. This shift creates an “aging signature” like a wrinkle that we can observe in the measured force more clearly than in the measured voltage at relevant discharge ranges and rates. We collected data from aged cells to verify that the model can capture the evolution of the electrode “age wrinkles” in the electrical and mechanical domains under a wide variety of operating conditions. Intellectual Merit: We verify our hypothesis that the differential force (dQ/dF) is more effective for higher C-rates than the differential voltage (dQ/dV) due to the dependence of the mechanical behavior more directly on particle average concentration [2]. We also determine the relationships between degradation, peak shifting, and relevant charge rates for the first time. A public database of aging data with cell swelling behavior has been curated and is widely used. Broader Impacts: By serendipity, we found that cell swelling can also inform us of gas accumulation inside cells and can lead to early detection of thermal events [1]. This research is now expanded to future chemistries such as Li-Silicon or solid state sodium. The fundamental results have been and will continue to be included in the curriculum, such as a) the graduate level battery control course (ME-565) with an enrollment of 45-85 students and 10-30 distance-learning students from industry each semester, b) undergraduate modeling course ME360 with 350 students/year, c) summer bootcamps with community college and high school students and teachers. 

[1] T. Cai, A. G. Stefanopoulou, and J. B. Siegel, “Modeling Li-Ion Battery Temperature and Expansion Force during the Early Stages of Thermal Runaway Triggered by Internal Shorts,” J. Electrochem. Soc., vol. 166, no. 12, pp. A2431–A2443, 2019.

[2] P. Mohtat, S. Lee, J. B. Siegel, and A. G. Stefanopoulou, “Towards better estimability of electrode-specific state of health: Decoding the cell expansion,” J. Power Sources, vol. 427, pp. 101–111, Jul. 2019.

[3] P. Mohtat, S. Lee, J. B. Siegel, and A. G. Stefanopoulou, “Reversible and irreversible expansion of lithium-ion batteries under a wide range of stress factors,” J. Electrochem. Soc., vol. 168, no. 10, p. 100520, Oct. 2021.

 


Last Modified: 05/09/2023
Modified by: Jason Siegel

Images (1 of )
  • Up to 40 Li-ion battery pouch type cells could be tested simultaneously in a thermal chamber using the low-cost expansion measurement fixtures created with NSF funding.
    Anna Stefanopoulou
    Copyrighted
    Jason Siegel
    Rack of Batteries measuring expansion over life
  • Models which describe both the reversible and irreversible expansion of the battery over a wide range of operating conditions were developed to improve battery health diagnostics.
    Sravan Pannala and Peyman Mohtat
    Copyrighted
    Jason Siegel
    Modeling cell Expansion
  • Low cost fixtures enable measurement of many cells at once, to develop models of battery behavior over a wide range of operating conditions.
    Jason Siegel and Sravan Pannala
    Copyrighted
    Jason Siegel
    Inductive Displacement Sensor for Measuring Battery Expansion
